docs.lead_paragraph: The clock is running out on Johnson & Johnson's efforts to stop the federal government from barring Medicare coverage of its implantable spinal disk, Charité. Yesterday was the end of the 30-day comment period on the proposal to designate the device as not ''reasonable and necessary'' therapy for Medicare patients suffering from severe lower back pain. The stage is now set for a final ruling in mid-May.

headline.main: Spinal Disk Closer to Losing Medicare Aid

docs.abstract: Clock is running out on Johnson & Johnson's efforts to stop federal government from barring Medicare coverage of its implantable spinal disk Charite; March 17 was end of 30-day comment period on proposal to designate device as not 'reasonable and necessary' therapy for Medicare patients; stage is set for final ruling in mid-May (M)
docs.snippet: The clock is running out on Johnson & Johnson's efforts to stop the federal government from barring Medicare coverage of its implantable spinal disk, Charité.

docs.lead_paragraph: The largess demonstrated by the Senate in padding its budget with billions of dollars in additional spending this week showed that lawmakers are no different from many of their constituents: they don't mind pulling out the charge card when money is tight. Just hours after opening a new line of credit through an increase in the federal debt limit, the Senate splurged on a bevy of popular programs before approving a spending plan that was as much a political document as an economic one, its fine print geared to the coming elections.
docs.abstract: Carl Hulse analysis holds that largess demonstrated by Senate in padding its budget with billions of dollars in additional spending showed that lawmakers are no different from many of their constituents: they do not mind pulling out charge card when money is tight; contends that administration and Congress act as if surplus that greeted Pres Bush when he checked into White House is still in bank, rather than recognizing that whatever windfall was available then was eaten up and more by tax cuts (M)
docs.snippet: Hours after opening a new line of credit by increasing the federal debt limit, the Senate splurged on a bevy of popular programs.

docs.lead_paragraph: David Wexler, a former dermatologist, was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to 20 years in prison for illegal narcotics distribution after he improperly prescribed drugs like Xanax and Percocet for a patient in an insurance fraud scheme. He was convicted of submitting thousands of false claims to Medicare for surgery on Barry Abler, including claims for 1,300 facial incisions. Mr. Wexler collected $425,000 for the claims, the trial showed, and he paid Mr. Abler $700 a month and supplied him with drugs to secure his cooperation. Mr. Abler died of a drug overdose in May 2001. JULIA PRESTON (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Dermatologist Sentenced To 20 Years

docs.abstract: Former dermatologist David Wexler is sentenced in federal court in Manhattan to 20 years in prison for illegal narcotics distribution of prescription drugs to patient Barry Abler in Medicare fraud scheme; Abler died of drug overdose in 2001 (s)
docs.snippet: David Wexler, a former dermatologist, was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to 20 years in prison for illegal narcotics distribution after he improperly prescribed drugs like Xanax and Percocet for a patient in an insurance fraud scheme....

docs.lead_paragraph: A study suggests that antidepressants work better than psychotherapy in preventing relapses in elderly men and women who have recovered from depression.

headline.main: Bush Opposes Extending Deadline for New Medicare Drug Program

docs.lead_paragraph: Chrysler, which is trying to persuade union members to accept less-generous health care benefits, said Wednesday that most of its salaried employees would pay more for their health coverage beginning next year. Chrysler also said that it expected to cut 10 percent to 15 percent of its 14,900 salaried jobs in the United States, or up to 2,235 positions, as part of a plan by its parent company, DaimlerChrysler, to eliminate 6,000 jobs worldwide through 2008.

headline.main: Chrysler's Salaried Workers to Pay More for Health Care

docs.abstract: Chrysler says most of its salaried workers will pay more for their health coverage beginning in 2007; says it expects to cut 10 percent to 15 percent of its 14,500 salaried jobs in US, or up to 2,235 positions through voluntary buyout programs (M)
docs.snippet: Chrysler also said that it expected to cut 10 percent to 15 percent of its 14,900 salaried jobs in the United States.

docs.lead_paragraph: As contract talks started yesterday, the president of the union representing 28,000 doormen, elevator operators and other service workers at 3,500 New York apartment buildings predicted that negotiations would be especially tough this year. Michael Fishman, the union president, said soaring health costs would make this round of talks the most difficult in a decade, raising the possibility of a strike when the union's three-year contract expires at 12:01 a.m. on April 21.

headline.main: As Contract Talks Start, Building Workers Focus on Health Care Costs

docs.abstract: Contract talks begin between New York City building service employees and management, and they are expected to be especially difficult this year; Local 32BJ of Service Employees International Union represents 28,000 doormen, elevator operators and other service workers at 3,500 apartment buildings; management negotiators say they are in no mood to pay far more for health insurance because residential buildings are already being squeezed by spiraling fuel costs and rising taxes (M)
docs.snippet: As contract talks started yesterday, the president of the union representing 28,000 doormen, elevator operators and other service workers at 3,500 New York apartment buildings predicted that negotiations would be especially tough this year.
